article:
The 'International Socialist Tendency (IST)' is an international grouping of
unorthodox Trotskyist organisations {{cite web
 | url=http://www.marxists.org/history/etol/entries/ist.htm title=International
 | Socialist Tendency publisher=Marxists Internet Archive date= accessdate=25
 | September 2010
}} based around the ideas of Tony Cliff, founder of the Socialist Workers
Party (SWP) in Britain {{cite web
 | url=http://www.marxists.de/intsoctend/foot/tonycliff.htm title=Tony Cliff
 | publisher=REDS â Die Roten date=11 April 2000 accessdate=25 September 2010
}} (not to be confused with the unrelated Socialist Workers Party in the
United States). It has sections across 27 countries; however, its
strongest presence is in Europe, especially in Britain.

The politics of the IST are similar to the politics of many Trotskyist
Internationals. Where it differs with many is on the question of the Soviet
Union, the IST adopting the position that it was a "state capitalist" economy,
rather than a "degenerated workers' state" {{cite web
 | url=http://www.marxists.org/archive/cliff/works/1955/statecap/intro.htm
 | title=State Capitalism in Russia publisher=Marxists Internet Archive
 | date=1947 accessdate=22 September 2010
}} along with their theories of the "permanent arms
economy" {{cite web
 | url=http://www.anu.edu.au/polsci/marx/contemp/pamsetc/perm/perm.htm title=A
 | Permanent Arms Economy publisher=Marxism Page date=1967 accessdate=25
 | September 2010
}} and "deflected permanent revolution". {{cite web
 | url=http://www.marxists.org/archive/cliff/works/1963/xx/permrev.htm
 | title=Deflected Permanent Revolution publisher=Marxists Internet Archive
 | date=1963 accessdate=25 September 2010
}} The IST sees the often referred to "socialist" countries, such as the
former Eastern Bloc states, China, Vietnam, North Korea and Cuba as an inverse
of classical Marxism, arguing they are "Stalinist" in nature. {{cite web
 | url=http://www.marxisme.dk/arkiv/molyneux/realmarx/index.htm title=What is
 | the real Marxist tradition? publisher=Marxisme Online date=1983 accessdate=22
 | September 2010
}}

Unlike many international tendencies the IST has no formal organisational
structures and has only ever made one publicly known decision, which was to
expel the US International Socialist Organization (ISO) from its ranks. {{cite web
 | url=http://www.angelfire.com/journal/iso/istmeeting.htm title=Report on
 | International Socialist Tendency meeting 5 July 2001 publisher=SWP Central
 | Committee date=5 July 2001 accessdate=23 September 2010
}} However, the antecedents of the IST go back to the 1950s when the
founders of the British Socialist Review Group (SRG), around Cliff, were
expelled from The Club and thus from the Fourth International. {{cite web
 | url=http://www.bolshevik.org/Pamphlets/CWI/CWI_history.html title=A Brief
 | Sketch of the Militant Tendencyâs History publisher=Committee for a Workers'
 | International date=18 May 2008 accessdate=31 May 2011
}}
headings: Non-aligned IST organisations which hold to its basic positions
Organisations which originated in the IST but have significantly changed their political orientation
